パッケージ org.wcardinal.controller.annotation

Annotation Interface OnTime

@Documented @Target(METHOD) @Retention(RUNTIME) public @interface OnTime
Marks an annotated method as a method invoked by execute(String, Object...), timeout(String, long, Obejct...), interval(String, long) or interval(String, long long, Object...). The method must be a thread safe. 
 @Controller
 class MyController extends AbstractController{
   @OnCreate
   void init(){
     timeout( "foo", 1000 );
   }

   @OnTime( "foo" )
   void foo(){
     // Called from the init method
   }

   @OnTime( "foo" )
   void bar(){
     // Called from the init method
   }
 }
When the value() is omitted, method names are used to identify which @OnTime methods should be invoked. 
 @Controller
 class MyController extends AbstractController{
   @OnCreate
   void init(){
     timeout( "foo", 1000 );
   }

   @OnTime
   void foo(){
     // Called from the init method
   }

   @OnTime
   void bar(){
     // Not called from the init method
   }
If the value() contains "*", annotated methods are invoked regardless of a name. 
 @Controller
 class MyController extends AbstractController{
   @OnCreate
   void init(){
     timeout( "foo", 1000 );
   }

   @OnTime( "*" )
   void bar(){
     // Called from the init method
   }
When a method is called, a controller owing the method is not locked. Accessing fields of the controller owing the method, thus, is not thread safe. 
 @Controller
 class MyController {
   @Autowired
   SString name;

   int score;

   @OnTime
   void foo(){
     // Not thread safe
     score = 12;

     // Thread safe
     lock();
     try{
       score = 12;
     } finally {
       unlock();
     }

     // Thread safe because set(Object) locks the `MyController` internally.
     name.set( "Cardinal" );
   }
 }
関連項目:
  • ControllerContext.execute(String, Object...)
  • ControllerContext.timeout(String, long, Object...)
  • ControllerContext.interval(String, long)
  • ControllerContext.interval(String, long, long, Object...)
